steps.content:
Maize is Ethiopia’s most important cereal in terms of production.

Ethiopia is the fifth largest producer of maize in Africa.

94% of maize production is done by smallholder farmers.

steps.title: stressors  & shocks
steps.content: In which locations is maize production exposed to climate variability and shocks and what is the severity?

steps.aside:
stressors  & shocks

Maize production & variability in short rains

Ethiopia

Livelihoods

49% of Ethiopia is used for rained agriculture

INSIGHTS PROVIDED BY CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL

steps.content:
Since 1981, the rainfall during the short rainy season has decreased by as much as 24% per decade in areas important for maize.

10% of the area currently used for maize production has been impacted by this decrease.

steps.content:
In areas of climate stress, fertility rates are >5 children per woman.

The population of Ethiopia is projected to increase from 98,942,102 to 142,900,000 by 2030, creating further stress.

Source: International Futures (IFs) forecasting system and the Pardee Center for International Futures at the University of Denver.

steps.aside:
Vulnerability

Illiteracy rate for women with short rains

steps.content:
In areas of stress fewer than half of all women can read and less than 31% of women have access to mass media.

These factors inhibit resilience.

steps.title: insights
steps.subtitle: agricultural livelihoods & climate change in ethiopia
steps.content:
Climatic changes in primary maize growing seasons will cause lower food production in areas with high sensitivity to changing precipitation patterns.

Access to information is critical to resilience of crop production; however, without careful planning, the impact of these interventions may be limited by high levels of illiteracy and lack of access to communications media, particularly among women.
